comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: This photo was taken looking in the opposite direction to the "last train" photo of 31 December 1958. On the right are the replaced buffer stops which got rammed through the wall in 1900. Daylight is showing between the end of the pitched roof and the curved end wall. The gap has since been filled in and this new roof has air-conditioning units on top. www.bing.com/maps/?v=2&cp=swp2ryggb923&lvl=19.09&... The tracks are on arches high above Harcourt Street. maps.google.co.uk/?ll=53.333687,-6.26291&spn=0.001001...

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/blackpoolbeach] Lovely aerial "shot", thanks.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 22919290@N08
comment._content: Much of the train shed remains in situ to the rear of the main building also. This is the interior of the train shed today, with the platform and tracks having been removed, but you can clearly see the entrances which would have led back into the main building. Even the decorative arch above one of the entrances can still be seen.

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/flyingsnail] Good set of photos on your eiretrains website. It looks like the trackbed was simply filled in up to the platform level, so there could still be the odd sleeper buried underneath.

comment.author: 22919290@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/blackpoolbeach] Thanks, I'd love to rip up the carpet just to see if there's anything but I suspect it's all covered in. I think the shed was used as a garage when the station had closed.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: When it was opened, Harcourt St station was described in Freeman's Journal and Daily Commercial Advertiser of 8th Feb 1859 as '... one of the most perfect of its class in the three kingdoms'.

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johnspooner] Good cutting from Freeman's Journal and Daily Commercial Advertiser There must have been a subway under the tracks to reach the "down rail" platform from the entrance hall on Harcourt Street, which was much lower than platform level. Lots of stair climbing. Both photos on NLI show the "up" platform from different directions.

comment.author: 22919290@N08
comment._content: There was a spiral metal stair case that led from the booking hall up to the single platform, I'm not sure if it's still in situ. I'm certain there was no second platform unless it was temporary, only the one on the up side. The Dublin South Eastern favoured single platforms at their principal stations, such as Bray and Dun Laoghaire. There were three tracks within the shed, all converging at the turntable. Interesting the article makes reference to the temporary terminus, this was located just south of the station on Harcourt Road.

comment.author: 22919290@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Oh believe me I'm no expert, I just pretend to be until found out! I'm sure O'Dea has some taken a little outside the shed, is there one that shows the signal cabin? Someone once asked me did I know of any photos of it.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/flyingsnail] Welcome to my world (fear of being found out!) :D We have 5 other O'Dea photos besides the one above, all taken at Harcourt Street Station on Monday, 12 January 1959, one of which is of the Signal Box. However, there's no digital image attached at the moment, but as far as I know, plans are afoot to add images for all 5,315 O'Dea photos!
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons
